title: 107_hr504
content: The "Community Access to Health Care Act of 2001" may be cited as the Act. The purpose of the Act is outlined in Section 2. The Act aims to assist communities and health care providers in developing integrated health care delivery systems for uninsured and underinsured individuals, focusing on coordination of services, infrastructure development, and provision of new Federal resources without supplanting existing funding. The Act aims to promote integrated health care delivery systems for uninsured and underinsured individuals through information sharing, clinical and financial coordination among providers, and provision of new Federal resources without replacing existing funding for low-income populations. The Community Access Program under the Public Health Service Act aims to provide grants to strengthen services for the uninsured and underinsured. The Secretary may grant funds to develop integrated health care systems serving uninsured and underinsured individuals, expanding services, and enhancing provider coordination. Eligible entities include public or nonprofit organizations like Federally qualified health centers and hospitals meeting specific criteria. The Secretary may grant funds to eligible entities like hospitals, public health departments, or provider consortia to provide coordinated health care services for specific communities, including uninsured individuals and special population groups. The Secretary may grant funds to eligible entities to provide a range of coordinated health care services for specific communities, including uninsured individuals and special population groups, with a preference for applicants that are health providers. To be eligible for a grant under this section, an entity must submit an application defining a community of uninsured and underinsured individuals in a specified area, identifying participating providers, and their contributions to care. Preference is given to health care providers. The curr_chunk outlines the requirements for a grant application under this section, including defining a community, identifying participating providers and their contributions, describing proposed activities, demonstrating the ability to involve traditional care providers, and developing capabilities. The current system for serving uninsured and underinsured individuals involves providers who traditionally provide care for the community. The consortium must demonstrate the ability to develop coordinated systems of care that provide a broad range of high-quality services, involve the community in program development, and ensure individuals are enrolled in public programs. The program proposed must demonstrate the ability to ensure participants are enrolled in public insurance programs, leverage various funding sources for sustainability, evaluate activities, show fiscal responsibility, and implement appropriate management systems. The program must demonstrate progress towards goals, fiscal responsibility, and commitment to serving the community regardless of ability to pay. Priority may be given to applicants with consortiums including public hospitals and other providers. The Secretary may prioritize applicants with consortiums including public hospitals, Federally qualified health centers, and other providers serving uninsured individuals. Preference may also be given to those targeting communities with a high percentage of uninsured individuals and expanding preventive care services. The program aims to expand preventive and primary care services for uninsured and underinsured individuals by improving coordination between healthcare and social service providers, collaborating with state and local governments, utilizing non-Federal contributions, and ensuring program sustainability. The grantee may use funds for expenses related to integrating a healthcare delivery system to provide a broad range of services, including primary, secondary, and tertiary care, substance abuse treatment, and mental health services. The grantee can use funds for a variety of services, such as primary, secondary, and tertiary care, substance abuse treatment, mental health services, patient care expansions, outreach activities, case management improvements, and coordination of transportation to healthcare facilities. The grantee can use funds for various activities including increasing outreach, improving case management, coordinating transportation to healthcare facilities, developing provider networks, recruiting and training personnel, acquiring technology, closing service gaps, improving provider communication, and implementing shared information systems. Improvements to provider communication, shared information systems, and other activities to increase access to the uninsured are eligible for funding. No more than 15 percent of the grant funds can be used for direct patient care. The Secretary can allocate up to 3 percent of funds for technical assistance, expert consultation, meetings, dissemination of information, and evaluation. The Secretary may allocate up to 3 percent of funds for technical assistance, expert consultation, meetings, dissemination of information, and evaluation. Grants under this section require recipients to maintain their non-Federal expenditures at or above previous levels. The recipient of a grant under this section must report annually to the Secretary on progress towards grant goals and provide additional information as required. The Secretary may not renew a grant unless reasonable progress is demonstrated. Each grant recipient must undergo an independent annual financial audit. The entity receiving a grant must undergo an independent annual financial audit. The Secretary can provide technical assistance to meet grant requirements. $250,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2002, with additional funding for fiscal years 2003 through 2006.
